UC0001.description: Prohibited web applications such as file sharing platforms (i.e. Box, Dropbox, etc.), and games can be detected, and filtered by modern web proxy solutions/next generation firewalls. Existing exceptions, or new application instances should be reviewed to ensure appropriate usage.
UC0001.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0001.name: Detection of new/prohibited web application

UC0002.description: Prohibited protocols such as IRC, FTP, or Gopher could indicate malicious activity on insecure systems located on the network. Consider Intra-network communication, and organization accepted communications from the Internet.
UC0002.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0002.name: Detection of prohibited protocol (application)

UC0003.description: Server Operating Systems, and Application services often generate email to support general purpose, or application specific functions. Configuration management is often used to identify servers generating e-mails, as well as maintaining recipient lists.
UC0003.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0003.name: Server generating email outside of approved usage

UC0004.description: Excessive email generation by authorized users could indicate the presence of malware designed to send spam, or abuse company resources. An application owner, or admin could also be attempting to solve a business problem outside of company policy. This use case focuses on email that is generated from endpoint networks. Operating systems should also be considered since servers can use user credentials to send messages; when this is allowed, false positives could be generated.
UC0004.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0004.name: Excessive number of emails sent from internal user

UC0005.description: Authorized, or unauthorized users may attempt to modify existing hardened configuration policies, or disable monitoring tools.
UC0005.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0005.name: System modification to insecure state

UC0006.description: Manually clearing the security event log on a windows system is a violation of policy and could indicate an attempt to cover malicious actions.
UC0006.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0006.name: Windows security event log purged

UC0007.description: Logon event properties could indicate account misuse, or as an indication of compromise. Compare the identified purpose of the account with the context of the logon to determine its authority.
UC0007.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0007.name: Account logon successful method outside of policy
UC0007.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

UC0008.description: Excluding computer accounts in active directory, an account with new activity that has not been active in the previous thirty days is suspicious.
UC0008.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0008.name: Activity on previously inactive account

UC0009.description: An Internet facing authentication system has allowed authenticated access from a risky source network.
UC0009.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0009.name: Authenticated communication from a risky source network

UC0010.description: Identify users gaining access via an unapproved or unknown access control. This could indicate malicious activity or an internal control failure.
UC0010.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0010.name: Detect unauthorized use of remote access technologies

UC0012.description: Increase the risk score of users who have indication of adverse separation.
UC0012.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0012.name: Increase Risk Score of Employees before Adverse Separation

UC0013.description: Detection of change for groups used to control access for sensitive, regulated, or critical infrastructure systems.
UC0013.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0013.name: Monitor change for high value groups

UC0014.description: A human user may own multiple accounts. When the primary account of the human is expired, disabled, or deleted, we should expect no further activity from any other account owned by the user.
UC0014.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0014.name: Monitor Secondary Accounts after Primary Disabled

UC0015.description: Privileged user authenticates to more than X number of new targets successfully or is denied access to more than Y targets in the prior Z hours.
UC0015.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0015.name: Privileged User Accessing More Systems than Usual

UC0016.description: Batch, Windows Services, App Pools, and specially constructed Windows shells can access network resources. A small number of technical solutions will require this type of behavior, however, after excluding a white list of hosts or shares (such as sysvol or netlogon), such access attempts (success or fail) could indicate the presence of malware or attempts to elevate access.
UC0016.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0016.name: Computer Accounts Accessing Network Resources
UC0016.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

UC0018.description: Single IP address attempting authentication of more than two valid users within ten minutes where one or more unique accounts is successful, and one or more accounts is not successful against an approved SSO System.
UC0018.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0018.name: Unauthorized access SSO brute force

UC0019.description: A user on leave, vacation, sabbatical, or other types of leave should not access business systems.  This could indicate malicious activity by the employee or a compromised account.
UC0019.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0019.name: User authenticated to routine business systems while on extended absence

UC0021.description: Outbound communication with servers hosted in regions where the organization does not expect to have employees, customers, or suppliers.
UC0021.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0021.name: Communication outbound to regions without business relationship

UC0022.description: Endpoints attempting to communicate with an excessive number of unique hosts over a given time period may indicate malicious code.
UC0022.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0022.name: Endpoint communicating with an excessive number of unique hosts

UC0023.description: Endpoints communicating with an excessive number of unique destination ports could indicate malicious code probing for vulnerabilities. Certain server applications will arrange for communication on a high number port with the client such as ftp in passive mode and RPC on windows server.
UC0023.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0023.name: Endpoint communicating with an excessive number of unique ports

UC0024.description: The endpoint has attempted (success or fail) to communicate with an external server identified on a threat list using any protocol. An attempted communication could indicate activity generated by malicious code.
UC0024.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0024.name: Endpoint communicating with external service identified on a threat list.

UC0028.description: Multiple infections detected on the same endpoint in a short period of time could indicate the presence of an undetected loader malware component (apt).
UC0028.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0028.name: Endpoint Multiple infections over short time

UC0029.description: When a new malware variant is detected by endpoint antivirus technology it is possible the configuration or capability of other controls are deficient. Review the sequence of events leading to the infection to determine if additional preventive measures can be put in place.
UC0029.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0029.name: New malware detected by signature

UC0031.description: Accounts designated for use by services and batch process should start a limited set of child processes. Creation of new child processes other than the process name defined in the service or batch definition may indicate compromise.
UC0031.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0031.name: Service Account Starting Unexpected Processes

UC0035.description: Following a successful authentication, an attacker will attempt to determine what resources may be accessed without causing host intrusion or DLP technologies to detect activity. Commonly the attacker will enumerate and browse to shares, access email, access web applications, or connect to databases yet perform minimal or no activity.
UC0035.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0035.name: Compromised account access testing

UC0036.description: Following a successful authentication, an attacker will attempt to determine what resources may be accessed without causing host intrusion or DLP technologies to detect activity. Commonly the attacker will enumerate and browse to shares, access email, access web applications, or connect to databases yet not perform any or minimal activity. Typically Critical and Sensitive systems (during routine use) would not log access denied events.
UC0036.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0036.name: Compromised account access testing (Critical/Sensitive Resource)

UC0037.description: IDS devices reporting an attack using a signature not previously encountered are more likely be successful as new signatures are prompted by newly know attacks in the wild.
UC0037.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0037.name: Network Intrusion - New Signatures

UC0041.description: Authentication using insecure protocol SSHv1 detected. The legacy SSH protocol is inherently insecure indication of accepted SSHv1 sessions indicate a mis-configured system. Attempted and denied sessions indicate system probing or scanning.
UC0041.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0041.name: SSH v1 detected

UC0042.description: The public key utilized for authentication is recorded in the SSHD authentication log. Detection of a new key should be investigated to determine the owner of the key and validate authorization to access the resource.
UC0042.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0042.name: SSH Authentication using unknown key

UC0044.description: Even using SSH encryption, allowing password authentication to Linux/Unix systems over the network increases the attack surface and the possible impact of a compromised account. Investigate and resolve all instances of network authentication utilizing password.
UC0044.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0044.name: Network authentication using password auth

UC0046.description: Failure to synchronize time will impact the usefulness of security log data from the endpoint, and potentially prevent valid authentication.
UC0046.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0046.name: Endpoint failure to sync time

UC0049.description: Endpoint utilizing DNS as a method of transmission for data exfiltration, command and control, or evasion of security controls. Detected by large total size of DNS traffic OR large number of unique queries.
UC0049.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0049.name: Detection of DNS Tunnel

UC0050.description: Communication to an enclave network should only occur from another enclave network or sanitizing servers such as proxy or jump systems.
UC0050.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0050.name: Communication to an enclave network from an non-enclave network

UC0051.description: A user with continuous physical access failures could be someone searching for a physical vulnerability within the organization.  When this occurs in an area that is protecting CIP assets, it is something that should be followed up on immediately.
UC0051.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0051.name: Excessive physical access failures to CIP assets

UC0052.description: CIP assets require special protections; therefore, users that have not been vetted for CIP access, or should have had their access removed, should not have access.  System owners should be notified immediately should a non-CIP user attempt to access a CIP asset.
UC0052.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0052.name: Non-CIP user attempts to access CIP asset

UC0053.description: Detect attempted network intrusions by src_ip when the same source is observed with two or more unique destinations or one destination and two or more signatures
UC0053.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0053.name: Network Intrusion Detected

UC0054.description: Detect communication with command and control system from a compromised endpoint by identifying traffic allowed by the forward proxy with unknown or uncategorized sites where the endpoint communicates in at least 15 of the last 60 minutes (bins) and the destination is not on a noise suppression white list, the Alexa top 1M, or advertising domains list.
UC0054.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0054.name: Communication with command and control over HTTP(s)

UC0055.description: Detect when an endpoint is permitted external access by the web proxy where the category is known it indicate high risk by category. This list should not include undesirable but frequent categories such as social media, porn, time wasting, or advertising.
UC0055.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0055.name: Allowed Communication from a endpoint with external "risky" category

UC0057.description: Utilize email logs to identify users being welcomed to a cloud service on an identified risky list for the first time, notify the user to be aware the service is not approved and notify the users manager if known by identity.
UC0057.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0057.name: Identify users of Cloud Services that may not be approved

UC0065.description: Malware detection on an asset designated as compliance such as PCI, CIP or HIPPA requires review even when automatic cleaning has occurred.
UC0065.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0065.name: Malware detected compliance asset

UC0071.description: For employers that allow remote external connectivity the detection of two or more distinct values of external source IP address for successful authentications to a remote access solution in a short period of time indicates a likely compromise of credentials.
UC0071.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0071.name: Fast IP Change Between Remote Authentications

UC0072.description: Detection of an endpoint utilizing DNS as a method of proxying by querying for wpad.registrationdomain. Search for reply NXDOMAIN replies for A/AAA queries for wpad (bare host) and wpad.* where the domain portion is not a company owned domain.
UC0072.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0072.name: Detection of unauthorized using DNS resolution for WPAD

UC0073.description: Endpoint anti-malware detection event occurred where the malicious content was retrieved from an external URL. Possible indication of gaps in protection by web proxy, intrusion prevention, or advanced threat prevention. Use the information available for the event and determine how existing prevention controls can be modified to prevent future infections.
UC0073.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0073.name: Endpoint detected malware infection from URL

UC0074.description: IDS/IPS detecting or blocking an attack based on a known signature.
UC0074.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0074.name: Network Intrusion Internal Network

UC0075.description: Internal malware detection system such as FireEye devices reporting an attack.
UC0075.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0075.name: Network Malware Detection

UC0077.description: Maintain a tracking list of public domain suffix and data source "seen" by first epoch.
UC0077.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0077.name: Detection Risky Referral Domains

UC0079.description: Use of an identity identified as privileged to access a system for the first time within a rolling time period will trigger a notable event for review of access reason.
UC0079.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0079.name: Privileged Identity accessing New or Rare Sensitive Resource

UC0082.description: Communication from an enclave network may indicate a misconfiguration that could weaken the security posture of the organization or actual/attempted compromise. Communication filtered by the default rule implies no explicit permission for communication has been granted and should be reviewed. Consider ingress communication allowed by the default rule, and egress communication allowed or blocked.
UC0082.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0082.name: Communication with enclave by default rule

UC0083.description: Communication from a enclave network may indicate a misconfiguration that could weaken the security posture of the organization or actual/attempted compromise.
UC0083.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0083.name: New Rule allowing Traffic to or from Protected Network

UC0084.description: Define and maintain event types for unsuppressed notable events separately identifying review workflow, and triage SLA required.
UC0084.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0084.name: Monitor Execution of Triage Activity

UC0085.description: Communication to any web application server without filtering by a network web application firewall indicates a security misconfiguration.
UC0085.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0085.name: WAF Logs Show Unexpected Source IP

UC0087.description: Malware signature last updated on a asset designated as compliance such as PCI, CIP or HIPAA beyond SLA limits.  SLA in this use case refers to policy levels more than the traditional service level agreement.
UC0087.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0087.name: Malware signature not updated by SLA for compliance asset

UC0088.description: Detection of logon device by asset name (may require resolution from IP) when logon user does not match the owner and the number of unique owned devices is greater than two in the prior 24 hours.
UC0088.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0088.name: User account sharing detection by source device ownership
UC0088.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

UC0090.description: Detection of logon with the same account to a production and a non production environment. If an account (not user) has logged into more than one account, access management controls have failed and must be remediated.
UC0090.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0090.name: User account cross enclave access
UC0090.searchKeywords: login log in logon log on sign

UC0091.description: Using host based logs such as firewall or host intrusion detection for each asset with a governance category verify communication (accept or reject) has occurred with origination from one or more authorized platform vulnerability scanners (e.g. Rapid7, Nessus, OpenVAS).
UC0091.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0091.name: Validate Execution of Platform Vulnerability Scan

UC0092.description: Using web application access logs for assets deemed high/critical or with the governance attributed ensure the source IP address is one of the approved NLB or WAF devices. If WAF devices are placed in front of NLB devices ensure the first "x-forwardedfor" entry is the address of the WAF.
UC0092.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0092.name: Exception to Approved Flow for Web Applications

UC0095.description: High numbers of http error codes likely indicate a problem with the web application or server, or can be an indicator of malicious action.
UC0095.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0095.name: Detect Excessive Increase in HTTP Error Codes by Src

UC0096.description: Hosts with multiple indicators are likely infected with malware or successfully compromised.
UC0096.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0096.name: Network Intrusion Event Detected on Malware Infected Host

UC0097.description: Executive or VIP user credentials should be limited to assets that can be attributed to them. Any unusual or newly seen authentication activity should be considered suspect, where their credentials may be compromised.
UC0097.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0097.name: Newly Seen Authentication Behavior from VIP or Executive User

UC0098.description: Excessive proxy blocks can be a good indicator of a potential automated beacon or malware phone home.
UC0098.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0098.name: Excessive Proxy Denies by Single Host

UC0099.description: Detect excessive number of http status messages indicating error (400/500 errors), followed by an http status of 200 by src and uri. Can be a high indicator of unauthorized access or attempt to execute malicious commands.
UC0099.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0099.name: HTTP Brute Force Activity Detected

UC0100.description: Host and Network IDS event categories, detect events with a category of 'backdoor' or 'trojan' followed by a signature categorized as 'post exploit' on a given host or network within a given time period.
UC0100.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0100.name: Newly Seen File Successfully Executed by Web Application

UC0101.description: Detect attempts to gain persistence through newly seen/unauthorized scheduled tasks per host.
UC0101.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0101.name: Newly Seen Scheduled Task Detected by Host

UC0102.description: Traditional brute force attacks generate hundreds or thousands of failed access attempts against a single host. This is a variation of brute force, where the objective is to detect password guessing attempts that do not cause account lockouts or will not trigger other "failed access" notable events.
UC0102.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0102.name: Slow/Controlled Password Guessing Detected

UC0103.description: Detect lateral movement by searching for hosts with an unusually high number of connections to hosts it has never connected to before, within a given time period.
UC0103.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0103.name: High Number of Newly Seen Connections to Internal Hosts

UC0104.description: Host and Network IDS event categories, detect events with a category of 'backdoor' or 'trojan' followed by a signature categorized as 'post exploit' on a given host or network with a given time period.
UC0104.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0104.name: Chained Exploit Followed by Suspicious Events Detected

UC0105.description: Internal web applications often contain sensitive information and should be controlled. Multiple technologies can be used to detect rogue web applications, including Imperva WAF and/or Splunk App for Stream. Use one of these technologies to detect web applications in the environment that have not been seen internally before.
UC0105.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0105.name: Detect Newly Seen Public Web Application (Internal)

UC0106.description: Detect evasion/escalation technique where the password of a privileged user reset by another authorized account this should be rare and supported by appropriate trouble ticketing and authentication of the requesting user.
UC0106.help: Help not needed -- PS Use Case
UC0106.name: Reset of password other than by self for privileged user
